p: Increased N supply to the ecosystem via elevated N deposition induces N-fixing trees to downregulate N fixation to the greatest extent possible (Fig. 2a): facultative N-fixers completely downregulate N fixation and incomplete regulator N-fixers partially downregulate N fixation, whereas obligate N-fixers do not downregulate N fixation. Because facultative N-fixing trees completely downregulate N fixation (Fig. 2a), they have a negligible net CO 2–N 2O effect relative to non-fixing trees under high N deposition rates (Fig. 1c). Under high N deposition rates, N demand is satisfied by N deposition. As such, N fixed by obligate and incomplete regulator N-fixing trees due to sustained N fixation does not contribute to CO 2 sequestration (Fig. 2b). Rather, it contributes to soil N 2O emissions, which increase indefinitely with increasing N fixation (Fig. 2c). Thus, obligate and incomplete regulator N-fixing trees exhibit a considerable N 2O effect, yielding a net CO 2–N 2O warming effect relative to non-fixing trees (Fig. 1c).
